page.title: 08Transport - Tamar Valley
page.content: Before the railway was built nearly every thing was transported to and from the area by boat up and down the River Tamar. This was tin, copper and other ores from the mines, granite from Pearson's quarries for Plymouth docks and London paving, fruit and vegetables to Plymouth markets. Horse manure was carried up the river from Plymouth streets, limestone and coal for the local limekilns and goods for the mines. Food was locally grown so not much was bought from outside. With the coming of the Railway and the construction of Calstock Viaduct in 1908, the river traffic gradually died out because it was much quicker by train. This was much used until road transport became cheaper and more convenient. Now the A390 is the main connecting link with outside.
